awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract
In this project, funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, the research team is exploring fundamentally new reactions of nitriles. The proposal has impact in several areas; the elevation of nitrile chemistry, student training and development, and improving the ability of students' writing. The research falls into three broad areas that will develop new reactions of nitriles for the synthesis of cyclic, carbon-based scaffolds of relevance for the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and new materials. The first third of the proposal focuses on an extremely rapid synthesis of bicyclic nitriles, the middle third develops counter-intuitive methods of creating new carbon-carbon bonds, and the last section of the proposal develops new routes to reactive nitrile intermediates to control the three dimensional shape of nitrile-substituted scaffolds. The project continues an excellent track record in training students and post-doctoral associates, particularly minorities and women, to provide a stream of bright, highly motivated students for careers in science. The approach features vigorous research training with synergistic mentoring of undergraduate and graduate students and an emphasis on career life balance through group educational events and annual professional development retreats. Improved writing skills are taught through a review writing strategy that transitions undergraduate and graduate students from novice learners to expert practitioners. The approach simultaneously addresses a general writing deficiency in many students while instilling tools to critically evaluate the primary literature. Publishing the strategy in the Journal of Chemical Education should allow others to replicate the strategy with other students.

Technical Abstract
This project focuses on a blend of conceptually new bond constructions and new chemical entities, many of which challenge conventional processes. Preliminary results demonstrate the feasibility of preparing chiral decalones in a single synthetic operation, potentially replacing multi-step technology based on the Wieland-Miescher ketone. A highly unusual equilibration is under development which changes the stereochemistry of a quaternary bridgehead center; a process that challenges conventional notions. A counter-intuitive alkylation of metalated nitriles with unactivated alkenes is rapidly assembling tricyclic ketones. A complementary alkene addition uses S-ketenimines as particularly attractive nucleophiles to address two long-standing challenges: rapid access to stable ketenimine nucleophiles, and nitrile-based alkenylations. The last section of the proposal provides an orthogonal, innovative asymmetric alkylation with metalated nitriles. Collectively, the proposed research exploits the unique reactivity of nitriles consummate with the long-term objective of elevating metalated nitrile alkylations to a level of influence comparable to that of enolate alkylations.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Nitrile-containing molecules are extremely valuable as synthetic intermediates, are found in over 100 naturally occurring compounds, and in more than 30 high-value pharmaceuticals. Over the past four years we have developed fundamental insight into carbon-carbon bond-forming reactions that use the unique chemistry of metalated nitriles to assemble nitrile-containing molecules with excellent control over the molecular architecture. We have prepared a variety of cyclic and acyclic nitrile-containing scaffolds that are valuable precursors for the synthesis of complex molecules which, in one case, we have illustrated by preparing bioactive heterocycles. Two new synthetic methods have been developed which control the three-dimensional orientation of diverse substituents while two other methods have provided new routes to reactive nitrile-containing intermediates that extend current bond-forming reactions. A significant contribution of these advances is that we have engaged in mechanistic analyses that reveal the fundamental reactivity patterns that control the reactions which provides the foundation for others to employ the strategies in their own research.

In keeping with our desire to elevate nitrile chemistry, we have written two reviews to provide others with the understanding for adoption in their own research. Our review in Acc. Chem. Res. provides a concise summary of the continuum of metalated nitrile structures that is then related to differences in reactivity; in some cases one reactive intermediate can be selectively coaxed to react in two very different reaction manifolds. Our review of Diastereoselective Electrophile-Directed Alkylations describes a powerful, yet underutilized strategy for installing a new carbon-carbon bond with excellent control over the three dimensional orientation of both carbon atoms. The strategically is inherently efficient and uses readily available precursors.

The broader impact of this research includes providing insight into new reactivity modes of metalated nitriles, the dissemination of reviews to enable chemists to apply the advances in emerging areas, and the training of a suite of budding chemists needed to advance chemistry in the US chemical enterprise: the pharmaceutical chemistry, industrial manufacturing, and higher education. The project has led to four research publications and two reviews.

 


Last Modified: 09/18/2019
Modified by: Fraser F Fleming
